Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 IEEE/ACM International Conference on Utility and Cloud Computing (UCC) and Co-located BDCAT Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is request for "NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 IEEE/ACM International Conference on Utility and Cloud Computing (UCC) and Co-located IEEE/ACM International Conference on Big Data Computing, Applications and Technologies (BDCAT)".

Conference experience is critical for training undergraduate and graduate students to be well-prepared computing force in the future. This proposal aims to help develop the strong future workforce in computer and computational sciences by enabling students who would otherwise could not attend to participate in the UCC/BDCAT 2017 conference, stimulating students' enthusiasms in conducting cutting-edge research, and broadening their visions and interactions with top research scientists and professors in the field.

A successful engagement can have an impact in stimulating students' enthusiasm about utility computing, Cloud computing services, advanced distributed computing, and big data computing and applications (in contrast to Java and Web developments students are normally interested) and training future computing workforce for the nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is a travel grant to support students to attend The 10th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Utility and Cloud Computing (UCC 2017) and co-located 4th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Big Data Computing, Applications and Technologies (BDCAT 2017) that was held in Austin Texas from Dec 5th through Dec 8th of 2017.

The goal of this project is to develop a strong future workforce in computer and computational sciences by enabling students who would otherwise cannot attend to participate in the UCC/BDCAT 2017 conference, stimulating students' enthusiasms in conducting cutting-edge research, and broadening their visions and interactions with top research scientists and professors in the field.

Through this award, we were able to fund 16 students from U.S. institutions to attend the UCC/BDCAT conferences. We organized a "Graduate Student Symposium" dedicated for mentoring the travel grant awardees through the conference during the lunch session. The carried activities included 1) mentoring how to get the most out of conference experience, 2) training in thesis writing clinic for graduate students, 3) mentoring how to develop relationships with each other, 4) advising career selection, and 5) training in conference experience write-ups.

This project has an impact on the development of the future workforce in computer science and computational science for the nation.
